forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 1–2 weeks (NOAA typically posts global monthly rankings around mid-June for May).
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — the recent run of record-warm months and persistently extreme global sea-surface temperatures make another record the default expectation.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: NOAA ranks May 2025 as 2nd warmest (likely just behind May 2024) due to a modest step-down as El Niño wanes, slightly cooler land anomalies, or dataset-specific differences that keep the NOAA blend just below last year’s record.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Ocean warmth remains exceptionally high and, with lagged El Niño effects plus broad-based warmth on land, NOAA’s land+ocean blend edges out May 2024, placing May 2025 as the warmest May on record.
forecast.rationale:
Context: The last year has featured unprecedented global warmth, with many consecutive monthly records across multiple datasets. Sea-surface temperatures remained exceptionally high into spring 2025, and the lagged effect from the strong 2023–24 El Niño typically keeps global temperatures elevated into late spring. That sets a high prior that May 2025 will be near or at the top of the NOAA rankings.
Status quo weighting: Given the persistence of marine heat and recent record streaks, the status quo points to a Yes outcome. However, NOAA’s record to beat (May 2024) is a high bar, and small methodological or spatial anomaly differences can flip a close call.
Why not higher? (Ceiling): El Niño is transitioning toward neutral, which can shave a few hundredths of a degree off anomalies; NOAA’s methodology and baseline sometimes yield slightly lower rankings than Copernicus/ERA5 for tight races; if land areas cooled slightly relative to 2024 while oceans remained hot, May could land second.
Why not lower? (Floor): Background anthropogenic warming plus persistently extreme ocean temperatures and lag effects strongly support another top-1 or top-2 outcome; the odds of being far below record are low.
Updates that would move me up: Copernicus/ERA5 confirming May 2025 as warmest May on record; continued reports that global mean SSTs hit or stayed near all-time daily records through May; preliminary national datasets (e.g., GISTEMP) showing record May.
Updates that would move me down: Early major dataset(s) show May 2025 only 2nd warmest; NOAA’s preliminary daily or weekly ocean anomalies indicate a notable step-down vs May 2024; signs that land temperatures were distinctly cooler than last year.
Research assistant note: No additional information provided; forecast relies on known release timing, recent global temperature behavior, and cross-dataset patterns.
